player_decision.reason: 10bb effective heads-up with J8s plays well postflop in position; limping avoids getting 3-bet jammed by aggressive BB and preserves stack while retaining good playability.

In this heads-up scenario with Q5o, checking (Call) is preferable to see a cheap flop. As the big stack, there's no need to risk chips unnecessarily with a marginal hand. Allowing a free flop preserves your stack advantage while letting you evaluate the community cards before committing further.

With a pair of 5s and an Ace on the board, checking (Call) allows me to control pot size and avoid overcommitting. The Ace could make Bob cautious if he holds a weaker hand. By checking, I potentially induce a bluff from Bob or see a free turn card, preserving my stack for later aggression where I have stronger hands.
In position heads-up on A-7-5r after a check, a small stab folds out a lot of air/underpairs. We have some backdoor equity plus a gutshot; easy fold vs a raise.

Calling is the safest option here. My pair of 5s is vulnerable, and Bob's small bet could indicate a weak hand or a trap. By calling, I control the pot size and see the turn without overcommitting. Raising might inflate the pot unnecessarily, and folding gives up too easily. The Ace on the flop is concerning, but the minimal risk here justifies staying in to evaluate further streets.

In position with J8hh on A-7-5-6, we picked up an open-ender but face a range that includes many Ax and possible straights. Checking back controls pot, avoids getting check-raised off our equity, and lets us realize our 8 clean outs for free.

Given the tournament context and stack sizes (CharlieAI has 395 vs. BobAI's 165), shoving all-in applies maximum pressure. The River introduced a King, potentially improving Bob's hand, but with a weak pair of 5s, forcing Bob to commit his remaining stack risks his tournament life for a pot of 80. Bob’s earlier passive actions (calling post-flop) suggest medium strength, but he might fold marginal holdings like weak Aces or under pairs. An all-in exploit forces him to decide for his tournament survival, capitalizing on fold equity while avoiding a showdown where 5s likely lose.

We have J8 high on A K 7 6 5 after checking turn; opponent overbet-jams river, representing straights/two pairs/sets. Our hand is a very poor bluff-catcher and needs ~40% equity, which we don’t have versus this value-heavy range.
